The program focuses on next generation and foundational technology; enterprise architecture (including enterprise security architecture); IT portfolio management (investments, assets, services); application portfolio management and modernization (addressing technical debt); Enterprise data governance and management; Digital project oversight and project portfolio management; digital tools and ecosystems (Cloud); 	digital identity; enterprise cyber security risk management, and, cyber security event management. 

The program supports advancements in all these focus areas through encouraging collaboration between government institutions; engaging other governments (domestic and international); providing leadership and establishing governance; developing and implementing policy instruments; 	monitoring and overseeing departmental policy compliance and project management performance; and developing communities through learning and outreach activities.

The Management Accountability Framework (MAF) is an annual performance measurement tool focused on management practices across federal departments and agencies. Since its inception in 2003, MAF is used to set management expectations, measure performance across key areas of management, hold deputy heads accountable for organizational management, and support continuous improvement of management practices within departments. The assessments under MAF are ultimately intended to ensure that departments are undertaking the management practices to fulfil its organizational priorities and departmental mandates.

name_en: Acquired Services and Assets Policies and Initiatives
desc_en: The Acquired Services and Assets (ASA) program aims to strengthen the management of assets and acquired services within the Government of Canada through the development and implementation of policy instruments governing procurement, real property, materiel management, investment planning and project management. Through its policies, advice, support and oversight (monitoring, performance measurement and reporting), the ASA program assists federal departments and agencies in providing value for money and sound stewardship in the management of their assets and acquired services. The ASA program also strengthens the professional capacity of the Procurement, Materiel Management and Real Property Communities throughout the public service through a range of capacity building and community development initiatives.

The Digital Comptrollership Program is modernizing the financial and materiel management (FM) business model across the Government of Canada, to provide more timely access to reliable, consistent GC-wide information, and ensure that FM services better enable the delivery of programs for Canadians and remain cost effective and sustainable. The Program does so by designing standard, streamlined processes and common data structures, building modernized common systems to replace departmental platforms, helping managers, employees and financial and materiel management specialists to adopt new processes and systems, and aligning financial management systems investments with government priorities.

The internal audit function, which is independent of departmental management, informs the oversight of public resources throughout the federal public administration providing assurance as to whether government activities are managed in a way that demonstrates responsible stewardship to Canadians. 

The program is responsible for maintaining a modern internal audit policy suite and overseeing the function for the Government of Canada. Activities include monitoring of policy compliance, community outreach, conducting horizontal and core controls audits, provision of audit services to smaller departments, supporting recruitment, facilitating training and supporting the Departmental Audit Committee (DAC) appointment process and tenure management. 

These activities ensure that the internal audit function and the DAC provide Deputy Heads with assurance and advice to inform decision making in their departments and supports them in their role as accounting officer, as defined in the Financial Administration Act. 

The activities also ensure that the Comptroller General of Canada receives assurance and advice from audit committees and internal audit functions to inform decision making in a broader government context and to build and sustain the capacity of an independent, professional, and innovative internal audit community with the GC that adheres to professional standards and delivers timely value-added services that address current and emerging risks and opportunities.

name_en: Communications and Federal Identity Policies and Initiatives
desc_en: The Communications and Federal Identity Policy program is responsible for setting the requirements that enable departments to provide Canadians with information about Government of Canada decisions, policies, programs and services and support the use of a single, consistent, and coherent identity of the Government of Canada. The program provides guidance, policy interpretations and strategic advice; and monitors departmental policy performance. This includes community support and outreach.

The Canadian Digital Service works with partner organizations to improve government services for the people that use them; builds capacity across government for human-centred service design and iterative development; and provides advice to inform government decisions about digital investments.

In November 2020, the Government announced the updated Greening Government Strategy. The Strategy includes the following elements: a target to reduce federal facility and conventional fleet GHG emissions by 40% by 2025 relative to 2005-06 levels; and all of the government’s operations will target net-zero emissions by 2050 including buildings, fleet, procurement of goods and services, and national safety and security operations. The government will procure 100% emissions-free clean electricity by 2022, where available, and by 2025 at the latest for its operations.  The Strategy also includes commitments to divert waste, reduce water consumption, increase climate-resilience and retain and restore biodiversity in government operations. 

The Centre for Greening Government leads the implementation of the Greening Government Strategy. The Centre exercises its leadership through the setting of targets for the Government of Canada, alignment of Government of Canada policies to the Greening Government Strategy, administer the Greening Government Fund, implementation support and technical guidance to departments to facilitate compliance with the Strategy, brokering of targeted initiatives, developing communication products and learning events, and tracking and publicly disclosing the government’s environmental performance.

The Centre for Greening Government leads the implementation of the Greening Government Strategy. The Centre exercises its leadership through the setting of targets for the Government of Canada, alignment of Government of Canada policies to the Greening Government Strategy, implementation support and technical guidance to departments to facilitate compliance with the Strategy, brokering of targeted initiatives, developing communication products and learning events, and tracking and publicly disclosing the government’s environmental performance.

The Office of Public Service Accessibility (OPSA) was created in August 2018 to support the Government of Canada in meeting the requirements of the Accessible Canada Act. OPSA is charged with developing an overarching strategy and implementation plan to help the federal public service be ready to meet the requirements of the Act and establishing a Centralized Enabling Workplace Fund to invest in new tools, research and projects to improve workplace accommodation practices and eliminate barriers that contribute to the need for individual accommodation. 



OPSA is a hub – a source of strategic advice regarding accessibility issues related to employment, the built environment, information and communications technologies, the procurement of goods and services, program and service delivery, workplace accommodation and the development of a disability inclusive culture for all Government of Canada departments and agencies. It leverages, through extensive and targeted engagement, the expertise of partners in other levels of government and both the private and non-profit sectors according to the principle of nothing without us, to establish the public service of Canada as the gold standard of an accessible and inclusive workplace.

To accelerate the shift to simpler and more modern, secure and efficient government services for the Canadian population, the Digital Government program provides all departments with a government-wide vision and tools focused on advancing digital service delivery, cybersecurity, recruitment and privacy.

The program provides support for initiatives in four areas:  

1. excellence in technology and operations, which includes a risk-free technical landscape and modern, flexible, people-centric practices

2. simpler, more reliable digital services and programs supported by government-wide data integration and management

3. policies and frameworks designed for a modern, secure and privacy-enabled digital government

4. empowered employees with optimized and enhanced digital talent across the GC, recognizing that digital talent across Canada is in high demand.

To achieve this goal, the program provides all departments with standardized policies, guidelines, objectives, implementation and performance tools, strategic advice, intergovernmental agreement templates, and support through functional communities and government-wide learning and development events.

The Employee Relations and Total Compensation (ERTC) Sector negotiates terms and conditions of employment and equips departments and agencies to meet their labour relations, classification and compensation management accountabilities. ERTC supports the Treasury Board of Canada (TB) in its role as plan sponsor of the public service pension and benefits plans and as the Employer for departments and agencies of the Core Public Administration (CPA) and the Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP).  

Key activities include setting terms and conditions of employment of non-executive employees in the CPA and providing support for separate agencies outside the CPA. ERTC also negotiates changes to benefits plans and collective agreements, develops and implements public sector pension legislation, including monitoring and administrative management of the federal public service pension and benefit plans. The program maintains job evaluation and qualification standards, modernizes the classification program, and advises departments and Ministers’ offices on labour relations, classification, occupational health and safety and compensation issues, including strategic direction to prevent and resolve workplace harassment. Finally, it implements and monitors compliance with pay equity requirements in the CPA and the RCMP.

The Pension and Benefits Management program manages the public service pension and group insurance benefit plans, including disability insurance and the public service health care and dental care plans and supports the funding and financing of the public sector pension and benefit plans.



The program fulfills its responsibilities by undertaking policy analysis; conducting studies; reviewing plan provisions; monitoring the financial status of pensions and benefits plans; leveraging technologies; streamlining administrative processes; and aligning plans and services more effectively with the Government of Canada’s priorities and industry best practices.



The program also negotiates with bargaining agents and key stakeholders on changes to benefit plans through various boards and committees to ensure that terms and conditions of employment are comparable and sustainable. 



In addition, the program manages stakeholder relations with respect to the plans, and provides information to members on plan benefits and plan changes.



NOTE: Pension and Benefits Management was merged with Employment Conditions and Labour Relations to become Employee Relations and Total Compensation for 2022-23.

The Workplace Policies and Services program supports the Treasury Board in establishing strategic direction for people management and for the use of official languages for work and services to the public.  It seeks to provide the foundation for excellence to manage a productive public service that is healthy, safe, and inclusive. In doing so, the program contributes to the attraction, retention, and development of a skilled and diverse workforce that can communicate in both official languages. 



To achieve its goals, the program develops and supports implementation of policies, directives and standards for: people management; values and ethics; official languages for communications with the public; workforce bilingualism; workplace well-being; and diversity and inclusion. 



Other key activities include: supporting governance mechanisms; supporting leadership and professionalism for the human resources community; engaging and collaborating with a broad range of expert communities, stakeholders and partners; and providing advice and guidance to public service organizations including, for official languages, to the broader range of public sector institutions, such as Crown corporations and separate agencies.

The Treasury Board of Canada Secretariat holds funds centrally to supplement appropriations, from which allocations are made on behalf of other federal organizations. Payments and receipts can also be made on behalf of these organizations. These funds provide payments for the employer’s share of health, income maintenance and life insurance premiums; payments to or in respect of provincial health insurance plans, payroll taxes and provincial taxes; the reimbursement of employment insurance premium rebates; and payments of administration costs.

The Executive Leadership and Development (ELD) program fosters government-wide excellence in executive leadership and management through modern and agile policy frameworks. The program supports deputy heads and heads of human resources with policy advice and support to enable a high-performing and diverse executive cadre.  



ELD’s key activities include: strategic direction and oversight in the areas of executive performance; leadership and talent management; terms and conditions of employment; classification and organization design; compensation; collective management and resourcing of Assistant Deputy Minister positions; and co-governance and co-delivery of the Joint Learning Program with the Public Service Alliance of Canada.

People Management Systems and Processes (PMSP) program supports the Chief Human Resources Officer of Canada who, as the business owner, is responsible for providing coordinated and strategic oversight for enterprise-wide HR systems, processes, standards and controls. PMSP is currently executing the business owner functions in response to the Phoenix pay crisis and the NextGen Initiative which aims to replace Phoenix with the intent to ensure a modern HR infrastructure is integrated with enterprise-wide systems. 



Key areas of the program include providing strategic direction for the development, implementation and maintenance of common HR systems and processes, standards and controls for the Government of Canada; collaborating with partners to develop and operationalize the HR business frameworks and enable infrastructure; supporting effective change management for key stakeholders; monitoring compliance to ensure People Management tools and services meet the needs of the Government of Canada now and into the future; and maintaining important relationships with bargaining agents.  



The areas of the focus for this program, as it pertains to fully operationalizing the business owner role, represents the long-term commitment that is critical to enabling world-class people management in the Government of Canada.

The Research, Planning and Renewal program leads research and experimentation of innovative practices across the public service to manage people effectively in preparation for the future of work. It is responsible for the collection, consolidation and reporting on data analytics for administrative and performance data and surveys related to people management.  



The program aligns its analysis on people management with the strategic outcomes and government-wide objectives of maintaining an agile, equipped and inclusive public service. RPR supports foresight capacity and establishes key partnerships to further research within and outside government on the key people management issues.



The program contributes to evidence-based decision-making by leading the development of an enterprise-wide strategy for managing data on human resources. The program also enables government-wide leadership on strategic planning for workforce management to build capability for the future of work and excellence in managing people.



The program provides a central service to Office of the Chief Human Resources Officer sectors in order to strengthen people management planning, strategy and governance.

The Secretariat supports Treasury Board (TB) Ministers in their role as a committee of the Queen’s Privy Council for Canada by providing advice on Governor in Council regulatory and Order-in-Council (OIC) matters. The program provides leadership and management of the Government’s regulatory function and is responsible for federal regulatory policy and oversight promoting good regulatory practice; regulatory policy research and analysis; targeted Regulatory Reviews; Canada’s Centre for Regulatory Innovation (CRI); the Annual Regulatory Modernization Bill process; and supporting the External Advisory Committee on Regulatory Competitiveness (EACRC) and regulatory reconciliation and cooperation forums established between Canada-US, Canada-European Union, and domestically between the federal government, provinces and territories. Engaging stakeholders, such as the Canadian public, industry associations, businesses, and other groups also plays an important role in the delivery of program objectives. TB Ministers and federal departments and agencies are the primary clients of the program.

Management and oversight services involve activities undertaken to ensure that federal government service operations and programs comply with applicable laws, regulations, policies and plans. Activities include providing strategic direction, governance and corporate planning; allocating resources and taking investment decisions; and analyzing exposure to risk and determining appropriate countermeasures.

Communications services involve activities undertaken to ensure that Government of Canada communications are effectively managed, well-coordinated and responsive to the diverse information needs of the public. These activities ensure that the public receives government information, and that the views and concerns of the public are taken into account in the planning, management and evaluation of policies, programs, services and initiatives. 
This Internal Services category refers to communications that are corporate in nature, affecting the entire department whether through internal communications to all employees or external communications on behalf of the department.

Legal services involve activities undertaken to enable government departments and agencies to pursue policy, program and service delivery priorities and objectives within a legally sound framework. Activities include the provision of the following services: legal advisory, litigation and legislative services.

Human resources management services include activities related to supporting human resources (HR) planning and reporting; reviewing, assessing and developing organizational design; reviewing and assessing job descriptions and classifications; supporting staffing processes; collecting and processing employee information related to compensation, leave and transfers; identifying and coordinating organization-wide training and learning requirements; promoting values, ethics and employment equity; managing employee recognition and awards programs; addressing workplace management and labour relations; and developing and maintaining HR information systems within the organization.

Financial management services involve activities undertaken in the department to ensure the prudent use and stewardship of financial resources in an effective, efficient and economic manner. Activities include planning, budgeting, accounting, costing, reporting, control and oversight, analysis, decision support and advice, and financial systems.

Information management services involve activities undertaken to achieve efficient and effective information management to support program and service delivery; foster informed decision making; facilitate accountability, transparency, and collaboration; and preserve and ensure access to information and records for the benefit of present and future generations. Information management (IM) is the discipline that directs and supports effective and efficient management of information in an organization, from planning and systems development to disposal or long-term preservation.

Information technology services involve activities undertaken to achieve efficient and effective use of information technology (IT) to support government priorities and program delivery, to increase productivity and enhance services to the public. IT management activities includes planning, developing (or procuring), and operating IT computing, telecommunications, infrastructure and applications.

Real property management services involve activities undertaken to ensure that real property (e.g., land, bridges, and buildings) is managed in a sustainable and financially responsible manner throughout its life cycle to support the cost-effective and efficient delivery of government programs. Most federal real property services are captured under specific program expenditures. As an Internal Services category, real property management services are limited to those expenditures associated with office accommodations that are not funded by Public Services and Procurement Canada (PSPC), as well as to expenditures for real property services. Also included in this category are the expenditures of any FTEs that provide real property policy advice to real property practitioners throughout the department.

Materiel management services involve activities undertaken to ensure that materiel can be managed by departments in a sustainable and financially responsible manner that supports the cost-effective and efficient delivery of government programs. Treasury Board’s Policy on Management of Materiel defines materiel as “all movable assets, excluding money or records, acquired by Her Majesty in right of Canada.” Movable assets are tangible and include a broad range of goods such as equipment (e.g., office, information technology, telecommunications, scientific), furniture and furnishings, and larger goods (e.g., vehicles and ships). Most materiel expenditures are specific program expenditures. However, as an Internal Services category, materiel management services include the expenditures from policy and administrative support for those who manage and dispose of materiel throughout the department.

Acquisition management services involve activities undertaken to support the acquisition of goods, services or construction services identified as necessary for a department to fulfill its ongoing mandate and purpose. These activities include processing, monitoring and reporting, developing and implementing departmental policies and procedures, and activities that support the sound management of procurement contracts.

Regulations are one of the key tools used by government to achieve public policy outcomes, such as strengthening safety measures for Canadians. Our Program aims to align Canada’s aviation policies, guidelines, regulations and standards with international civil aviation standards. We interact with many partners and stakeholders when: Conducting policy, research and regulatory development; and Implementing and delivering changes to our Program. Specifically, our partners include: Foreign governments (e.g., to sign technical agreements); The International Civil Aviation Organization to contribute to and influence the development and implementation of standards/recommended practices; Industry (e.g., to determine who can perform certain duties within an organization); and Other Programs within Transport Canada (e.g., to mitigate risks, such as when dangerous goods are transported by air) and Government departments (e.g., the Transportation Safety Board).

Our Program is guided by the standards and regulatory requirements contained within the Canadian Aviation Regulations. We are responsible for: licensing personnel (i.e. pilots, aircraft maintenance engineers and air traffic controllers); administering medical assessments of licensed aviation personnel; providing operating certificates to organizations (i.e. airlines, other air operators and aircraft maintenance organizations); certifying aeronautical products, thereby enabling Canada’s aerospace manufacturing sector to sell their products globally (e.g., aircraft, landing gear, etc.); verifying the safety of aerodromes; and producing and distributing safety-related publications (e.g., airworthiness directives) and education material to aviation industry stakeholders and the general public to maintain and reinforce safety standards.

Thousands of passengers and goods are transported by air both within Canada and to markets abroad, every single day. Within the Aviation Security Regulatory Framework, our Program develops and uses a balance of tools to promote a harmonized aviation security regulatory framework for Canadians and the Canadian aviation industry. We are responsible for developing, administering and overseeing the policies, regulations and standards needed to: support the secure conduct of day-to-day activities within the Canadian aviation sector, and ensure Canada’s aviation security regulatory framework is aligned with international standards. We achieve this by: working in partnership with our federal government partners, various partners such as the International Civil Aviation Organization and other foreign governments, and industry stakeholders, to reduce Canada’s and global air security risks; and by using a risk-based approach that prioritizes areas of security that are of greatest concern for both Canadians and the Canadian aviation industry.

Our Aviation Security Program is tasked with ensuring that Canadian aviation regulated entities (i.e., aerodromes, air carriers, Primary Security Line Partners (namely a tenant with a restricted area access point to the aerodrome), the Canadian Air Transport Security Authority and Air Cargo Security Program participants) remain in compliance with the Canadian aviation security regulatory framework. The approach we take focuses on: ensuring each regulated entity can build their own internal security expertise, as well as develop effective incident management procedures, plans and tools; promoting compliance by conducting inspections and tests; and taking enforcement actions when required.

Aircraft Service Directorate (ASD) is a Federal Government internal aviation service provider that operates a fleet of 50 aircraft including 23 Transport Canada (TC) owned aircraft, 23 Canadian Coast Guard (CCG) Helicopters and 4 Department of National Defense (DND) Challengers with a staff of 390 people located on 15 bases across Canada.  

The organization that operates under the Canadian Aviation Regulations (CARs), holds an Air Operator Certificate (AOC), is an Approved Maintenance Organization (AMO), an Approved Engineering Organization (AEO) and an Approved Training Organization (ATO) in aircraft maintenance.  It delivers aeronautical services to Transport Canada and Other Governmental Departments (ODGs) and supports the Government of Canada in response to natural disaster and surveillance of the waterways through the National Aerial Surveillance Program.



Consequently, ASD target groups are Federal departments such as CCG and DND, as well as programs within Transport Canada such as Civilian Aviation, Public Servants and surveillance officers.

Our Program contributes to protecting the public interest by developing, regulations, standards and policies that establish minimum requirements for safety and environmental protection and promote safe marine practices. In doing so, we facilitate: ensure the safe movement of goods by the marine transportation system.

The scope of the regulatory framework includes, vessels, their equipment, cargoes and the people onboard. The objectives include the protection of the physical safety of people onboard commercial and recreational vessels, marine-related property, our Canadian waterways and the marine environment. Our partners include foreign governments, the International Maritime Organization, marine industry and other government departments, such as Fisheries and Oceans Canada and the Canadian Coast Guard.

Our Program provides oversight and certification of the marine industry, including domestic non-pleasure (commercial) craft and pleasure craft and foreign commercial vessels, to enhance safe operation of the marine transportation system by promoting and verifying compliance with regulatory requirements. We support Authorized Representatives, who are responsible for the compliance with the marine safety regulatory framework, by promoting education and awareness of the rules, regulations and safe operating practices; by producing and distributing safety-related publications and education material to industry stakeholders and the general public to maintain and reinforce safety standards. We verify compliance before issuing certificates to vessels that have to have a certificate to operate and carry out risk-based inspections of smaller vessels that do not need certificates. Additionally, we are responsible for registering and licensing commercial vessels and pleasure craft, and providing data on fleet composition. We carry out assessments, validations, inspections, audits and, when necessary, enforcement actions. Lastly, we inspect foreign commercial vessels entering Canadian waters for compliance with all applicable international and Canadian requirements. We also certificate seafarers and marine pilots.

Our Program is guided by the standards and regulatory requirements contained within any applicable marine regulations under our jurisdiction. We are responsible for: licensing and certifying seafarers, including screening candidates for Certificates of Competency in accordance with the Marine Personnel Regulations; administering medical assessments of licensed marine personnel; registering vessels; providing operating certificates to organizations (i.e., vessel owners, other marine operators and maritime maintenance organizations); certifying maritime products, thereby enabling Canada’s maritime manufacturing sector to sell their products; reviewing vessel plans and issuing inspection certificates; licensing pleasure craft users; and producing and distributing safety-related publications, and education material to marine industry stakeholders and the general public to maintain and reinforce safety standards.

A safe and secure marine transportation system is essential for the efficient flow of trade and the Canadian economy. Our Program: uses various tools (e.g., legislation) to promote a consistent marine regulatory framework, thereby allowing for a viable and secure marine transportation system for Canadians and industry; aims, in consultation with marine stakeholders, to streamline and harmonize Canada’s regulatory requirements so that we can meet our international security obligations; and coordinates marine security policy and regulatory development across the Government of Canada by leading the interdepartmental Marine Security Working Group. We also develop and implement strategic maritime response information sharing arrangements with the United Kingdom, Australia, New Zealand and the United States, as well as with states with territory in the Arctic, so that we can rapidly share information with our allies, to address emerging maritime safety and security threats and events.

Our Program is an important contributor to Canadian security. We are responsible for overseeing all matters related to marine safety for Canadian vessels, foreign vessels in Canadian waters and Canadian marine facilities and ports. We achieve this by: supporting the marine industry’s compliance with the security regulatory framework through education and awareness services, security and threat and risk assessments and validations, inspections and audits, including security plan approvals, incident management services and, when necessary, enforcement; monitoring threats/events domestically and abroad; developing procedures, plans, exercises and tools, coordinating maritime emergency management activities in partnership with all federal departments and agencies that have roles and responsibilities for marine security in Canada; and providing marine security expertise and support to our partner departments and agencies within the Marine Security Operations Centres.

Our Program is tasked with administering and enforcing the Navigation Protection Act, including: authorizing ‘works’ (i.e., any human-made structure, device or thing) on Canada’s navigable waterways; and managing obstructions and enforcing prohibitions (i.e., depositing, throwing and dewatering (the removal of water)). Our Program also administers and enforces parts of the Canada Shipping Act, 2001, including: receiver of Wreck Program as a custodian of a wreck; and Private Buoy Regulations for privately owned floating information markers (e.g., for speed limits). We also have responsibilities under the Ferry Cable Regulations, Navigable Waters Bridges Regulations and the Navigable Waters Works Regulations. Our Program serves many different clients, such as: Canada’s industrial (e.g., mining), tourism and recreation sectors; the general public, including private property owners; and provincial, territorial and municipal governments and other federal government departments.

With more than 44,000 kilometres of track and 23,000 public and private rail crossings, Canada’s rail network is the fifth largest in the world. Our Program’s mandate is to ensure that Canada’s federally regulated rail network is safe, efficient and environmentally responsible. To achieve this, we provide a balance of tools, including: legislation (i.e. the Railway Safety Act); regulations (e.g., the Grade Crossings Regulations, the Railway Safety Administrative Monetary Penalties Regulations); rules (e.g., the Canadian Railway Operating Rules); and policies, standards and guidelines. By setting the conditions within which federally regulated railway companies are permitted to operate, we ensure that goods and passengers are transported safely.

We oversee federally regulated passenger and freight railway companies to provide Canadians a safe, efficient, and environmentally responsible rail network. We are responsible for verifying that federally regulated railways are compliant with railway safety legislation, regulations, rules and engineering standards through: conducting safety inspections of equipment, operations, track, bridges, crossings, and signals, to verify compliance with federal rules and regulations; performing Safety Management Systems (SMS) audits (which verify the development and implementation of a railway’s SMS); and, when required, taking enforcement action.

Transport Canada’s Rail Safety Improvement Program provides federal funding in the form of grants or contributions to provinces, territories, municipalities, and local governments, road and transit authorities, crown corporations, for-profit and not-for-profit organizations (including academia), Indigenous groups, communities and organizations and individuals/private landowners to help improve rail safety, address climate change resiliency, and reduce injuries and fatalities related to rail transportation. The program’s objectives are to improve rail safety, contribute to increasing safety at grade crossings and along rail lines, address climate change resiliency, and increase public confidence in Canada’s rail transportation system. The Rail Safety Improvement Program builds on three previous rail safety programs – the Grade Crossing Improvement Program; the Grade Crossing Closure Program; and Operation Lifesaver – with an increased overall funding level, an expanded list of eligible recipients and a broadened scope of projects that can be funded to enhance rail safety. The program provides a comprehensive approach to improving the safety of rail transportation across Canada, through two key components: 1) Public Education and Awareness; and 2) Infrastructure, Technology and Research.

name_en: Multi-Modal and Road Safety Regulatory Framework
desc_en: Our Program’s top priority is to reduce the number of motor vehicle injuries and fatalities on Canada’s roads by actively protecting and improving road and motor vehicle safety. Working with stakeholders, we: develop evidence-based policies, guidance, legislation and regulations concerning the safety requirements for motor carriers, new domestic and imported motor vehicles, tires and child restraints that provide Canadians with high levels of motor vehicle safety, while facilitating choice in the marketplace, and industry with a regulatory framework that encourages innovation and the development of new safety technologies; inform Canadians about motor vehicle safety, importation and child restraint issues via our toll-free telephone line and by posting notices and recalls on our website; and conduct research to determine the need for new or amended regulations and standards in both the North American and global context.

Road transportation is an integral part of the daily lives of most Canadians. In order to help prevent road-related deaths and injuries, our Program serves drivers, passengers and other road users by overseeing the safety compliance of vehicles and equipment used on Canada’s roads. Our work covers the types of motor vehicles defined in regulation (e.g., cars, trucks, motorcycles, trailers, etc.), as well as equipment defined in legislation (e.g., tires and child car seats). We assess compliance with the associated safety requirements contained in the legislation and regulations through: inspections and audits of companies; destructive and non-destructive testing of vehicles and equipment; investigations of alleged safety-related defects in the design, construction or functioning of vehicles and equipment; monitoring recalls of vehicles and equipment; and, if necessary, enforcement action, when companies or persons are not compliant with any applicable Acts or regulations.

Furthermore, we create frameworks that improve the quality and consistency of our department’s activities through technical training which ensures that our inspectors and technical experts have and maintain the required competencies to do their job, and enforcement support (litigation support services for our officials when representing the Minister at tribunals; and enforcement and investigative support to our programs).

The Intermodal Surface Security Regulatory Framework (ISSRF) Program develops and amends policy and regulatory frameworks, instruments and guidance material for surface transportation security. This includes passenger and freight railways, urban transit and international bridges and tunnels.   

The Security Intelligence Assessment Branch (SIAB) provides intelligence and national security support to Transport Canada and its partners, in order to help ensure a safe and secure transportation system in Canada and abroad.

SIAB national security responsibilities include helping ensure Transport Canada compliance with Government of Canada national security and intelligence legislation, policy, transparency and external review requirements.  



The ISSRF Program aligns with TC’s core responsibility 1: a safe and secure transportation system and complements TC’s planning and reporting process by tying into result 2: a secure transportation system. The program tags include regulation / legislation, and safety or security program / service. The target groups are transportation industry, provincial & territorial governments, and federal departments and / or agencies. The expected outcomes are stakeholders are aware of the regulatory requirements under the Transportation of Dangerous Goods (TDG) by Rail Security Regulations and the Passenger Rail Transportation Security Regulations.

Millions of people annually rely upon using Canada’s road, rail and marine networks for their travel and shipping needs. Our Program is responsible for ensuring that companies are in compliance with all intermodal surface security laws, regulations, policies and standards. We accomplish this by: conducting oversight activities of our clients, such as compliance inspections, outreach activities to our transportation partners and providing them with guidance materials, and threat and risk assessments. The program works closely with railway carriers/loaders, passenger companies, and international bridge and tunnel owners and operators to share information and best practices to improve the security level of surface transportation. It also works closely with other levels of government and federal government departments/agencies in helping to improve surface transportation security. The goal of our work is to see that the security of the surface and intermodal transportation system across Canada is maintained to the highest possible standard.

name_en: Transportation of Dangerous Goods Regulatory Framework
desc_en: Our Program achieves results through the development of risk-based policies, procedures, guidelines, equivalency certificates, regulations, and standards to ensure dangerous goods are handled and transported in a manner that ensures public safety. Our areas of activities include: the development of Canadian regulations for the transportation of dangerous goods; collaboration with the United States and international partners (via the United Nations and other forums) to harmonize Canadian regulations and standards;  and the development of national and international standards for the manufacture, selection and use of dangerous goods means of containment (e.g., tank cars and cylinders).Our Program is key to ensuring that dangerous goods are handled and transported in the safest possible manner and is responsible for: leading the development of Canadian regulations for the transportation of dangerous goods; collaborating with the United States and international partners (via the United Nations and other forums) to harmonize Canadian regulations and standards, as appropriate; developing national and international standards for the manufacture, selection and use of dangerous goods means of containment (e.g., tank cars and cylinders); and issuing various types of means of containment registrations to industry. This is achieved through the development of risk-based policies, procedures, guidelines, equivalency certificates, regulations and standards to promote public safety in the handling, offering for transport, transporting, or importing of dangerous goods.

Our Program is responsible for verifying and ensuring compliance with the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Act, 1992 and the Transportation of Dangerous Goods Regulations. Our Program operates across multiple modes and jurisdictions, and our oversight activities are focussed on Canada’s transportation system, nationally and at point of entry. Our Program plays a key role in having dangerous goods transported in a manner that ensures public safety. We support industry’s compliance with the regulatory framework through: inspections and enforcement; the approval of Emergency Response Assistance Plans, the approval and issuance of Equivalency Certificates; and awareness and outreach.

name_en: Transportation of Dangerous Goods Technical Support
desc_en: Incidents involving dangerous goods can potentially put human life and health, property, and the environment at risk. Our Program is a technical centre of expertise on the transportation of dangerous goods that is responsible for: operating the Canadian Transport Emergency Centre (CANUTEC) 24 hours a day, 7 days a week to provide scientific expertise following a transportation of dangerous goods incident; providing onsite technical expertise during incidents through our response program; developing guidance materials on emergency response, such as the Emergency Response Guidebook, to support first responders; determining and promoting best practices related to chemical, biological, nuclear, and explosive incidents involving releases of dangerous goods; and maintaining partnerships with first responders, public authorities and stakeholders, by participating in simulations and training exercises.

The Transportation Security Clearance (TSC) Program is mandated under the Aeronautics Act to conduct checks and verifications of persons who are required to obtain a TSC for the purpose of assessing whether an applicant meets the standards set out in the Program.  

The Marine Transportation Security Clearance (MTSC) Program, under the Marine Transportation Security Act (MTSA), conduct checks and verifications of persons who are required to obtain a MTSC for the purpose of assessing whether an applicant meets the standards set out in the Program. 

Both the TSC and MTSC Programs, which fall under the responsibility of Security Screening Certification, promote a secure transportation system by preventing unlawful acts of interference by assessing a person's suitability to hold a TSC.

The safety and security of Canada and Canadians is one of the Government of Canada’s key functions. Our Program is responsible for administering Transport Canada’s responsibilities under the Emergency Management Act as they relate to: prevention/mitigation strategies; emergency preparedness; and response to and recovery from transportation-related emergencies. Our Program’s important role in emergency preparedness is to ensure that we are prepared for, and able to respond to, emerging threats and situations that may impact the national transportation system. We achieve this by: collaborating closely with internal partners (e.g., other Programs within the Department), industry and stakeholders (e.g., Airport Authorities); and employing the standardized Incident Command System approach during all incidents and emergencies, which streamlines response operations, improves departmental coordination, and contributes to protecting life, safety and the environment.

The effects of climate change and the emission of greenhouse gases (GHG) and air contaminants, are among this century’s greatest challenges. Some of our Program’s responsibilities include: developing, strengthening and overseeing compliance with policies, voluntary agreements and regulations that reduce Canada’s GHG emissions and air contaminants from the transportation industry; working with other federal programs that are mandated with reducing air pollutants and GHG emissions, to improve the health of Canadians and the environment; leading initiatives that advance understanding and encourage uptake of clean transportation technologies, such as the ecoTECHNOLOGY for Vehicles Initiative and pursuing research, development and demonstration in the aviation, marine and rail sectors; and strengthening the transportation sector’s resilience to the impacts of a changing climate by developing policies and programs and working in partnership with jurisdictions and stakeholders.

Canada is home to the world’s longest coastline, and our waterways are a key component of the nation’s overall transportation system. Our Program is responsible for protecting, managing, restoring and improving Canada’s marine environment. Some of the initiatives we undertake include: the Oceans Protection Plan, that improves marine safety and enforces responsible shipping practices, protects Canada’s waters and marine environment, restores and protects marine ecosystems and habitats, and is collaborative with Indigenous and coastal communities; and administering clean water regulatory frameworks, which set the rules governing the protection of the marine environment (e.g., from pollution, spills, invasive species, the usage of ballast water, etc.); and oversight, which contributes to reducing pollution from vessels, by monitoring marine transportation firms’ compliance to the regulatory frameworks through surveillance, inspections, audits, monitoring and enforcement.

Our Program contributes to an environmentally responsible and resilient national transportation system by ensuring that we: promote the greening of Transport Canada’s operations for owned and operated airports and ports, through the Greening Government Strategy; manage and/or remediate contaminated sites in accordance with applicable legislation and policies, incorporate federal transportation-related expert advice in support of impact assessment processes, and leading Transport Canada’s participation in the Fisheries and Oceans-led Marine Spatial Planning process. Our Program plays an important role in terms of supporting local economic development, health, social and economic impacts on Indigenous groups and communities.

The assessment, adoption and seamless integration of new and emerging innovation in the transportation system plays an important role in supporting the Government's economic, safety, environmental and social objectives. Our Program exists to further transportation innovation and help Transport Canada, industry and Canadians transition towards the integration of new and emerging transportation technologies.

We achieve this by: providing leadership and supporting policy development on transportation innovation; helping to advance regulatory development that allows for the safe adoption and integration of new, emerging and evolving transportation technology; developing partnership with other governments, industry, and academics; promoting Canadian expertise in transportation technology; providing funding for projects, research and other activities that promote innovative transportation systems; and supporting government priorities related to innovation, infrastructure and the smart planning of cities.

Our program is operating as a Centre of Expertise, which provides services to other Transport Canada Programs to advance the Department’s Indigenous reconciliation efforts and working with federal partners to support “whole-of-government” initiatives (i.e., across multiple departments). We assist decision-makers by: Providing advice on best practices for consultation and engagement approaches across a broad range of departmental policy, program, regulatory and legislative initiatives; promoting TC compliance with modern treaty agreements and legal obligations; participating in whole of government negotiations aimed at advancing Indigenous interests and achieving Indigenous self-governance and self-determination; supporting and helping develop whole of government policies related to Indigenous issues; and maintaining ongoing relationships and partnerships with First Nations, Inuit and Métis Nation organizations and communities.

Our Program is tasked with administering and enforcing the Canadian Navigable Waters Act, including: authorizing ‘works’ (i.e., any human-made structure, device or thing) on Canada’s navigable waterways; and managing obstructions and enforcing prohibitions (i.e., depositing, throwing and dewatering (the removal of water)). Our Program also administers and enforces parts of the Canada Shipping Act, 2001, including : Private Buoy Regulations for privately owned floating information markers (e.g., for speed limits). We also have responsibilities under the Ferry Cable Regulations, Navigable Waters Bridges Regulations and the Navigable Waters Works Regulations. The Wrecked, Abandoned or Hazardous Vessels Act, which promotes the protection of the public, of the environment, including coastlines and shorelines, and of infrastructure by regulating abandoned or hazardous vessels and wrecks in Canadian waters and, in certain cases, Canada’s exclusive economic zone, and by recognizing the responsibility and liability of owners for their vessels, is an additional responsibility under the Navigation Protection Program. 

 

Our Program serves many different clients, such as: Canada’s industrial (e.g., mining), tourism and recreation sectors; the general public, including private property owners; and provincial, territorial and municipal governments and other federal government departments.

Our Program’s job is to create the policies, laws, regulations and international agreements that encourage Canada’s transportation sector to be: efficient movers of people and goods; and competitive, by creating choice for travellers and ensuring Canada’s transportation companies are internationally competitive. Our Program’s four separate divisions (Air, Marine, Surface and International and Trade) are responsible for: Overseeing the policy framework for airlines, airports, NAV CANADA and representing Canada at the International Civil Aviation Organization, and passenger and freight sectors for the rail and motor carrier industries in Canada and negotiating international surface agreements; Representing Canada’s marine sector at various forums (e.g., the International Maritime Organization) and monitoring Canada’s marine industry and ports system; and Establishing domestic and international relationships/partnerships that benefit Canada’s transportation industry.

Excellent policy decisions can be made when the best possible information is available. Our Program exists to conduct research and analysis to gain a better understanding of the key indicators that affect an ever-changing and evolving transportation sector. We achieve this by: collecting and analyzing relevant transportation data; monitoring and reporting on the performance and capacity of the national transportation system; and studying economic and societal impacts on current and future transportation system requirements. By doing this, we are then able to: make informed policy decisions, with a view to improving the efficiency of the transportation system; and identify where we should invest within Canada’s transportation system for the benefit of domestic and foreign travellers and businesses.

Our Program contributes to an efficient transportation system. We provide efficient and effective delivery of programs in the domains of transportation infrastructure and services in the air, marine and rail modes to ensure that transportation assets and services are available for use. The Program supports the operation of legacy transportation assets and services and the management of related capital requirements, the management of TC-owned real property, the stewardship of TC-owned assets managed by arms’ length third parties and the delivery of grant and contribution programs.                                 

Our Program plays an important role in terms of supporting local economic development, including tourism and recreation sectors; the general public; private sectors; provincial, territorial and municipal governments; as well as responding to social needs and serving local populations.

Our Program supports efficient market access for products through investment in Canada's trade corridors. It is composed of a number of different transfer payment programs, including the National Trade Corridor Fund (NTCF), and two sunsetting programs: the Gateways and Border Crossings Fund and the Asia-Pacific Gateway and Corridor Initiative. Through the management of infrastructure funds, and the use of policy based measures, the Program is responsible for providing funding to help infrastructure owners and users invest in strategic projects.

 

Projects funded under our Program: serve to increase and diversify the flow of Canadian trade around the world and the interconnectivity between trade infrastructure; support the flow of goods and passengers by reducing bottlenecks, and address capacity issues; help the transportation system withstand the effects of climate change and ensure it is able to support new technologies and innovation; address the unique transportation needs in Canada's territorial North to improve safety and foster economic and social development; and build on investments made by a variety of public and private sector partners.

Management and oversight services involve activities undertaken to ensure that federal government service operations and programs comply with applicable laws, regulations, policies and plans. Activities include providing strategic direction, governance and corporate planning; allocating resources and taking investment decisions; and analyzing exposure to risk and determining appropriate countermeasures.

Communications services involve activities undertaken to ensure that Government of Canada communications are effectively managed, well-coordinated and responsive to the diverse information needs of the public. These activities ensure that the public receives government information, and that the views and concerns of the public are taken into account in the planning, management and evaluation of policies, programs, services and initiatives. 
This Internal Services category refers to communications that are corporate in nature, affecting the entire department whether through internal communications to all employees or external communications on behalf of the department.

Legal services involve activities undertaken to enable government departments and agencies to pursue policy, program and service delivery priorities and objectives within a legally sound framework. Activities include the provision of the following services: legal advisory, litigation and legislative services.

Human resources management services include activities related to supporting human resources (HR) planning and reporting; reviewing, assessing and developing organizational design; reviewing and assessing job descriptions and classifications; supporting staffing processes; collecting and processing employee information related to compensation, leave and transfers; identifying and coordinating organization-wide training and learning requirements; promoting values, ethics and employment equity; managing employee recognition and awards programs; addressing workplace management and labour relations; and developing and maintaining HR information systems within the organization.

Financial management services involve activities undertaken in the department to ensure the prudent use and stewardship of financial resources in an effective, efficient and economic manner. Activities include planning, budgeting, accounting, costing, reporting, control and oversight, analysis, decision support and advice, and financial systems.

Information management services involve activities undertaken to achieve efficient and effective information management to support program and service delivery; foster informed decision making; facilitate accountability, transparency, and collaboration; and preserve and ensure access to information and records for the benefit of present and future generations. Information management (IM) is the discipline that directs and supports effective and efficient management of information in an organization, from planning and systems development to disposal or long-term preservation.

Information technology services involve activities undertaken to achieve efficient and effective use of information technology (IT) to support government priorities and program delivery, to increase productivity and enhance services to the public. IT management activities includes planning, developing (or procuring), and operating IT computing, telecommunications, infrastructure and applications.

Real property management services involve activities undertaken to ensure that real property (e.g., land, bridges, and buildings) is managed in a sustainable and financially responsible manner throughout its life cycle to support the cost-effective and efficient delivery of government programs. Most federal real property services are captured under specific program expenditures. As an Internal Services category, real property management services are limited to those expenditures associated with office accommodations that are not funded by Public Services and Procurement Canada (PSPC), as well as to expenditures for real property services. Also included in this category are the expenditures of any FTEs that provide real property policy advice to real property practitioners throughout the department.

Materiel management services involve activities undertaken to ensure that materiel can be managed by departments in a sustainable and financially responsible manner that supports the cost-effective and efficient delivery of government programs. Treasury Board’s Policy on Management of Materiel defines materiel as “all movable assets, excluding money or records, acquired by Her Majesty in right of Canada.” Movable assets are tangible and include a broad range of goods such as equipment (e.g., office, information technology, telecommunications, scientific), furniture and furnishings, and larger goods (e.g., vehicles and ships). Most materiel expenditures are specific program expenditures. However, as an Internal Services category, materiel management services include the expenditures from policy and administrative support for those who manage and dispose of materiel throughout the department.

Acquisition management services involve activities undertaken to support the acquisition of goods, services or construction services identified as necessary for a department to fulfill its ongoing mandate and purpose. These activities include processing, monitoring and reporting, developing and implementing departmental policies and procedures, and activities that support the sound management of procurement contracts.

To sustain a vibrant and profitable tourism industry in Canada; to market Canada as a desirable tourist destination; to support a cooperative relationship between the private sector and the governments of Canada, the provinces, and the territories with respect to Canadian tourism; and to provide information about Canadian tourism to the private sector and to the federal, provincial, and territorial governments.

The Health Care Benefits (HCB) Program provides eligible Veterans and other qualified individuals with financial support to access health care benefits (treatment benefits) to meet their identified needs. Treatment benefits include medical, surgical or dental examinations or treatment; surgical or prosthetic devices and aids and their maintenance; home adaptations to accommodate the use of devices or aids; preventive health care; pharmaceuticals; and travel and other expenses incurred to access these benefits.

Transition Services include funding for eligible participants to access medical, psychological and vocational rehabilitation or vocational assistance services needed to address barriers to re-establishment in civilian life arising from eligible health problems. Transition Services also include the Education and Training Benefit and Career Transition Services which provide funding for eligible participants to pursue education and training that will support them in a successful transition from military to civilian life, help them achieve their education and post-military employment goals, and better position them to be more competitive in the civilian workforce. Transition Services also include funding for medically released Veterans and families at Military Family Resource Centres across the country.

This program supports eligible Veterans and other individuals who require nursing home type care to meet their needs. The program works in cooperation with provincial agencies and long term care facilities to support eligible Veterans and other individuals in an appropriate long term care setting.

The Veterans Independence Program (VIP) is Veterans Affairs Canada’s national home and community care based program which assists eligible Veterans, and their primary caregivers and survivors, to remain in their homes and communities as long as possible by providing funding towards services which support and promote their independence.

The Caregiver Recognition Benefit formally recognizes the contribution caregivers make to the health and well-being of seriously injured Veterans who require continuous care and supervision, due to their service related physical and/or mental health condition(s). This benefit is paid directly to Veterans’ caregivers.

This program provides financial assistance to eligible Veterans, Merchant Navy Veterans, qualified civilians and their survivors, dependents and orphans. In recognition of War Service, qualified persons are provided with a regular, monthly income to meet basic needs and/or access to other Veterans Affairs Canada programs. Eligibility for War Veterans Allowance (WVA) is determined by the wartime service of a Veteran or qualified civilian, age or health, family income and residency. A surviving spouse, a surviving common-law partner or orphan may also qualify for a WVA.

The Income Support program comprises Income Replacement Benefit and Canadian Forces Income Support.  The Income Replacement Benefit is designed to provide income support to Veterans who are experiencing barriers to re-establishment due to a health problem resulting primarily from service. The benefit is available to Veterans and survivors for life, should they need it, and for eligible orphans. 



Canadian Forces Income Support (CFIS) is a tax-free monthly benefit available to help low income CAF Veterans, survivors, and dependent children. CFIS is available to Veterans who have completed the Rehabilitation Services and Vocational Assistance Program and are no longer eligible for the Income Replacement Benefit but have not yet successfully transitioned to civilian employment above a certain income level. Survivors may receive the benefit if the Veteran was in receipt of CFIS at the time of death.

The Veterans Emergency Fund provides funding to assist Veterans and their families during times of crisis and when facing emergency financial situations that threaten their health and well-being. Financial emergencies could include (but are not limited to) food, clothing, shelter, medical care, and expenses required to maintain safety and shelter.

name_en: Centre of Excellence on Post Traumatic Stress Disorder and Related Mental Health Conditions
desc_en: The Centre of Excellence on Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) and Related Mental Health Conditions will have a strong focus on the creation and dissemination of knowledge on prevention, assessment and treatment of PTSD and related mental health conditions for Veterans, RCMP and CAF members. It will result in better knowledge on how to prevent, assess and treat mental health issues. The objective is to increase the Canadian expertise, knowledge and transfer of knowledge on the subject of Canadian military and Veteran mental health, suicide prevention, and substance use disorder issues.

name_en: Veteran and Family Well Being Fund
desc_en: Veteran and Family Well Being Fund provides funding to organizations that conduct research and/or develop or implement innovative programs that improve the well-being of Veterans and their families. This funding is to foster innovation across private, non-profit and academic fields.

Disability Benefits comprise programs that recognize and compensate eligible Veterans, Canadian Armed Forces members, survivors, dependents, RCMP and some civilians for the effects of a service-related disability/death. This includes Disability Pensions, Pain and Suffering Compensation, Additional Pain and Suffering Compensation, Clothing Allowance, Attendance Allowance, Exceptional Incapacity Allowance, Critical Injury Benefit, Detention Benefit, Prisoner of War and Death Benefit. 



Monthly payments are paid for a Disability Benefit.  Disability Pensions and Pain and Suffering Compensation recognize and compensate a service-related disability. Additional Pain and Suffering Compensation recognizes and compensates Veterans experiencing barriers to re-establishment in post-service life due to a severe and permanent impairment. Clothing Allowance and Attendance Allowance are based on need. Exceptional Incapacity Allowance is a monthly benefit for eligible recipients. Critical Injury Benefit is a lump sum payment provided for one or more severe traumatic, service-related injuries or an acute disease. Detention Benefit and Prisoner of War compensation is provided for eligible periods of detention/prisoner of war status.  Survivors and dependents are recognized and compensated in the event of the member/Veteran’s death under the Death Benefit. Survivors and dependents may also be eligible for Pain and Suffering Compensation.

This program provides funding to organizations (private, non-profit, and academic sectors) undertaking research oriented projects and/or innovative initiatives to improve the well-being of military members, Veterans and their families.

The Research and Innovation program comprises the Centre of Excellence on Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder  and Related Mental Health Conditions, Research Funding, and the Veteran and Family Well-Being Fund. The Centre of Excellence on Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) and Related Mental Health Conditions  has a strong focus on the creation and dissemination of knowledge on prevention, assessment and treatment of PTSD and related mental health conditions for Veterans, RCMP and CAF members. It will result in better knowledge on how to prevent, assess and treat mental health issues. The objective is to increase the Canadian expertise, knowledge and transfer of knowledge on the subject of Canadian military and Veteran mental health, suicide prevention, and substance use disorder issues. The Research Funding program provides funding to organizations (private, non-profit, and academic sectors) undertaking research oriented projects and/or innovative initiatives to improve the well-being of military members, Veterans and their families.  The Veteran and Family Well-Being Fund provides funding to organizations that conduct research, develop or implement innovative programs that improve the well-being of Veterans and their families.  This funding fosters innovation across private, non-profit and academic fields.

Canada Remembers Program activities ensure that those who served in Canada’s military efforts are honoured and that the memory of their sacrifices and achievements is preserved. To this end, Veterans and those who died in service are publicly acknowledged through ceremonies and events, honours and awards, and the presentation and perpetual care of memorials, cemeteries and grave markers; and Canadians are aware of, and value, the contributions of those who served through a suite of resources that tell the story of our military history and the provision of funding for community-led commemorative initiatives.

In recognition of their service to Canada, the estates of eligible Veterans have access to financial assistance for a dignified funeral and burial. Under the Veterans Burial Regulations, assistance is available for Veterans whose deaths were a result of their service or whose estates do not have sufficient funds for a dignified funeral, burial, and grave-marking. The Funeral and Burial Program is administered by the Last Post Fund Corporation, an independent, non-profit organization, on behalf of Veterans Affairs Canada. This program is delivered through operating and maintenance funds and the Last Post Fund Grant.
The Office of the Veterans Ombudsperson reviews and addresses complaints, systemic and emerging issues regarding the programs, services and support provided by Veterans Affairs Canada.

Activities include providing strategic direction, governance and corporate planning; allocating resources and taking investment decisions; and analyzing exposure to risk and determining appropriate countermeasures.

Communications services involve activities undertaken to ensure that Government of Canada communications are effectively managed, well-coordinated and responsive to the diverse information needs of the public. These activities ensure that the public receives government information, and that the views and concerns of the public are taken into account in the planning, management and evaluation of policies, programs, services and initiatives.
